thread.title: Palmetto Sunrise: More Columbia meetings canceled

author: Cynthia Roldan
title: Palmetto Sunrise: More Columbia meetings canceled
text:
Sen. Harvey Peeler, R-Gaffney, (right) called for the creation of the committee. (AP Photo/Rainier Ehrhardt) × COLUMBIA — More meetings have been canceled in the state’s capital this week, as South Carolina focuses its attention on recovering from damaging historic floods.
The Joint Capital Bond Study Committee will no longer meet at 1 p.m., today. That’s a biggie, because the introduction and ultimate passing of the amendment that created this committee soured budget talks during the 2015 legislative session.
Senate Majority Leader Sen. Harvey Peeler, R-Gaffney, was the voice behind the amendment. At the time, he said the committee would study the state’s capital needs, so that it could come back to the 2016 legislative session with a clearer picture of what lawmakers should borrow money for.
Those capital needs might change now after the floods. Many of the state’s aging infrastructures have suffered from the historic downpour. And that could lead to borrowing money for other projects not initially envisioned.
The state’s chief budget writer in the Senate has already voiced the likely need to have the state borrow money during the upcoming legislative session. The meeting has not been rescheduled yet.
